The '''International Electrical Congress''' was a series of international meetings, from 1881 - 1904, in the then new field of [[electrical engineering|applied electricity]]. The first meeting was initiated by the French government, including official national representatives, leading scientists, and others. Subsequent meetings also included official representatives, leading scientists, and others. Primary aims were to develop reliable standards, both in relation to electrical units and electrical apparatus.
==Historical background== In 1881, both within and across countries, different electrical units were being used. There were at least 12 different units of electromotive force, 10 different units of electric current and 15 different units of resistance.<ref name=Petley483>{{cite journal |last=Petley, B.W.|first= |date=1994-95 |title=A Brief History of the Electrical Units to 1964 |url=http://stacks.iop.org/0026-1394/31/i=6/a=007 |subscription=yes|journal=Metrologia |volume=31 |page=483 |doi= |author-link= }}</ref>
Other international Congresses were held, and sometimes referred to as International Electrical Congress, Electrical Conference, and similar variations. Secondary sources make different judgments about how to classify the Congresses. In this article, the Congresses with representatives from national governments are identified as ''International Electrical Congress''. Other Congresses — often addressing the same issues — are identified here as ''Concurrent Related International Electrical Congresses''. Some of these related conferences were devoted to preparing for an International Electrical Congress.
In 1906 the [[International Electrotechnical Commission]] was created.<ref>{{cite web |title = Overview: Summary |work = IEC History |publisher = International Electrotechnical Commission |url = http://www.iec.ch/about/history/overview |accessdate = 2018-04-19}}</ref> Congresses were organised under its auspices were also sometimes referred to as ''International Electrical Congress''. In this article, Congresses organized by the Commission are listed under ''International Electrotechnical Congresses'', while other related Congresses are listed under ''Related International Electrotechnical Conferences''.
==International Electrical Congress<ref name=IEC>{{Cite web |url=http://www.iec.ch/si/history/historical_background.htm|title=Historical background |access-date=10 April 2018|website=[[International Electrotechnical Commission]]}}</ref>== ===1881 in Paris=== Held from 15 September-5 October 1881, in connection with the [[International Exposition of Electricity]]. [[Adolphe Cochery]], Minister of Posts and Telegraphs of the French Government, was the Chairman.<ref name=Petley483/> At the Congress, [[William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin|William Thomson]] (United Kingdom), [[Hermann von Helmholtz]] (Germany), and {{ill|Gilbert Govi|it|Gilberto Govi (fisico)}} (Italy) were elected as foreign vice-presidents.<ref name=lagerstrom>{{cite thesis |last=Lagerstrom |first=L.R. |date=1992 |title=Constructing uniformity: The standardization of international electromagnetic measures, 1860-1912 |type=doctoral dissertation |chapter= |publisher=University of California, Berkeley |url= |access-date=}}p. 77 </ref> About 200-250 persons participated,<ref name=lagerstrom/> and a proceedings was published in 1882.<ref>{{cite book |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Congrès International des électriciens, Paris 1881|url=https://archive.org/details/congrsinternati38unkngoog|location=Paris |publisher=G. Masson |page= |date=1882 |isbn=}} (in French)</ref> Notable participants included: [[Hermann von Helmholtz|Helmholtz]], [[Rudolph Clausius|Clausius]], [[Gustav Kirchhoff |Kirchoff]], [[Werner Siemens]], [[Ernst Mach]], [[John William Strutt, 3rd Baron Rayleigh|Rayleigh]], and [[Heinrich Lenz| Lenz]], among others.<ref name=Tunbridge34>{{cite book | author=Tunbridge, P. | title=Lord Kelvin: His Influence on Electrical Measurements and Units | location=Peter Peregrinus | publisher=London | year=1992 |page=34 | isbn=0-86341-237-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bZUK624LZBMC}}</ref>
====Important events==== The three main topics for the Congress were: electrical units, improvements in international telegraphy, and various applications of electricity.<ref name=lagerstrom/> The Congress resolved to endorse the 1873 [[British Association for the Advancement of Science]] proposal<ref>{{cite conference |url= https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/94452#page/7/mode/1up |title=First Report of the Committee for the Selection and Nomenclature of Dynamical and Electrical Units |date=1874|conference= Forty-third Meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science |publisher= John Murray |location= London |page = 223 |accessdate= 8 April 2018}} (Committee members: Professor [[Joseph David Everett]] (reporter), Sir W Thomson, Professor GC Foster, Professor JC Maxwell, Mr GJ Stoney, Professor Flemming Jenkin, Dr. CW Siemens, Mr FJ Bramwell)</ref> for defining the [[ohm]] and the [[volt]] as practical units,<ref name=Tunbridge35>{{cite book | author=Tunbridge, P. | title=Lord Kelvin: His Influence on Electrical Measurements and Units | location=Peter Peregrinus | publisher=London | year=1992 |pages=35-39 | isbn=0-86341-237-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bZUK624LZBMC}}</ref> and also made resolutions to define [[ampere]], [[coulomb]] and [[farad]],<ref name=IEC/> as units for current, quantity, and capacity respectively, to complete the practical system.<ref name=Tunbridge35/> It also resolved that an international committee should conduct new tests to determine the length of the column of mercury for measuring the ohm.
===1893 in Chicago=== Held from 21 - 25 August, in connection with the [[World's Columbian Exposition]], with almost 500 participants.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |last=Martin|first=T.C.|contribution=History of the Congress|title=Proceedings of the International Electrical Congress held in the City of Chicago August 21st to 25th, 1893|date=1894|location=New York| page=xxii |publisher=American Institute of Electrical Engineers}}</ref> [[Elisha Gray]] was the Congress president. A proceedings was published.<ref>{{cite book |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Proceedings of the International Electrical Congress|url=https://archive.org/details/proceedingsinte01chicgoog|location=New York |publisher=American Institute of Electrical Engineers |page= |date=1894 |isbn=}}</ref>
: Refinements to the units of measurement, including the [[Clark cell]], were discussed.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Carhart, H.S. |date=18 Oct 1895 |title=Proceedings of the International Electrical Congress, Chicago, 1893 [review]|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/2/42/525 |journal=Science |volume=2 |issue=42|pages= 525-526 |doi=10.1126/science.2.42.525 |url-access=subscription|access-date=10 Apr 2018|bibcode=1895Sci.....2..525C}}</ref> Laid down rules for the physical representation: ohm, ampere and volt. Ohm and ampere were defined in terms of the [[CGS#CGS approach to electromagnetic units|CGS electromagnetic system]].<ref name=IEC/> The units were named ''international'' to distinguish them from the 1881 proposal, hence [[International System of Electrical and Magnetic Units]].{{cn|reason=hard to find clear support for label|date=April 2018}}
===1900 in Paris=== Held in 18-25 August in connection with the [[Paris Exposition Universelle]]. [[Éleuthère Mascart]] was the Congress President. There were more than 900 participants, about half of which were from France, and about 120 technical papers presented.<ref name=Tunbridge46>{{cite book | author=Tunbridge, P. | title=Lord Kelvin: His Influence on Electrical Measurements and Units | location=Peter Peregrinus | publisher=London | year=1992 |page=46 | isbn=0-86341-237-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bZUK624LZBMC}}</ref> A two-volume proceedings was published in 1901<ref name=1900report>{{cite book |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Congrès International d'électricité|url=https://archive.org/details/congrsinternati00hospgoog|location=Paris |publisher=Gauthier-Villars |page= |date=1901 |isbn=|language=fr}}</ref> : Dealt mainly with magnetic units.<ref name=IEC/> During this Congress, names were proposed for four magnetic-circuit units in the C.G.S. System. Only two were accepted by vote: the C.G.S. unit for [[magnetic flux]] ( '''{{math|Φ}}''') was named ''[[maxwell (unit)|maxwell]]'' and C.G.S. unit of [[magnetising force]] (or [[magnetic field intensity]]) was named ''[[gauss]]'' ('''H''').<ref name=Kennelly33-144/> Some delegates mistakenly believed and reported that the gauss was adopted as the C.G.S. unit of [[flux density]] ('''B''').<ref name=Kennelly33-144/> This mistake has been reproduced in contemporary texts,<ref name=Tunbridge46/> which have cited a mistaken report.<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Kennelly |first=A.E. |date=5 March 1904 |volume=43|page=468|title=A historical sketch of International Electrical Congresses |url=https://archive.org/stream/electricalworld43newy#page/468/mode/1up |magazine=Electrical World and Engineer |location= |publisher= |access-date=20 April 2018}}</ref> It is relevant to note that the Congress's official formulation for the gauss was in French, ''{{lang|fr|champ magnetique}},''<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |author= |title= Congrès International d'électricité|chapter=Rapport de la Commission des Unités|url=https://archive.org/stream/congrsinternati00hospgoog#page/n395/mode/2up|location=Paris |publisher= |date= 1901 |isbn=|language=fr|page=384}}</ref> which would be translated into English as ''magnetic field'', which has been used to refer both to ('''B''') and ('''H'''), noted in [[Magnetic_field#Definitions,_units,_and_measurement|magnetic field]]. In 1930 the [[International Electrotechnical Commission]] decided that the magnetic [[Magnetic field#Definitions.2C units.2C and measurement|field strength]] ('''H''') was different from the [[Magnetic field#Definitions.2C units.2C and measurement|magnetic flux density]] ('''B'''), but now assigned the ''gauss'' to refer to magnetic flux density ('''B'''), in contrast to the decision from this Congress.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Kennelly |first1=A.E.|date=1933 |title=Conference of the Symbols, Units and Nomenclature (S. U. N.) Commission of the International Union of Pure and Applied Physics (I. P. U.), at Paris, in July, 1932, and Its Results |url= |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America |volume=19 |issue=1 |page=146 |doi= |jstor=85786|access-date= }}</ref>
===1904 in [[St.Louis, Missouri]]=== Held from 12-17 September 1904, in connection with the [[Louisiana Purchase Exposition]]<ref>{{cite journal |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=29 Jul 1904 |title=The International Electrical Congress|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/20/500/156 |journal=Science |volume=20 |issue=500 |pages=156-157 |doi=10.1126/science.20.500.156 |access-date=10 Apr 2018|bibcode=1904Sci....20..156. }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Transactions of the Transactions of the International Electrical Congress, St. Louis, 1904.|year=1905|publisher=J.B. Lyon|location=Albany, NY|url=https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/001616268/Home}}</ref> : Recommended two permanent international commissions, one about electrical units and standards, the other about unification of nomenclature and characteristics of electrical machines and apparatus.<ref name=IEC/> These recommendations are considered the seed that initiated the creation of the [[International Electrotechnical Commission]] in 1906.<ref name=founding>{{Cite web |url=http://www.iec.ch/si/history/founding_iec.htm|title=Founding of the IEC |access-date=13 April 2018|website=[[International Electrotechnical Commission]]}}</ref>
==Concurrent Related International Electrical Congresses== During the period that the Electrical Congresses were held, other conferences and international Congresses were held, sometimes in preparation to the official Electrical Congresses. These events are listed here.
===1882 in Paris===
''Conférence international pour la détermination des unités électriques'' (International Conference for Determination of Electrical Units)
Held 16-26 October. Was motivated by a resolution from the 1881 International Electrical Congress. A verbal transcript of the conference was published.<ref>{{cite book |title=Conférence international pour la détermination des unités électriques |date=1882 |author=Ministère des Affaires Étrangères |location=Paris | publisher=Imprimerie Nationale |url=https://archive.org/details/confrenceintern02trgoog |access-date=17 April 2018}} (in French).</ref>
===1884 in Paris=== ''International Conference for Determination of Electrical Units''
===1889 in Paris=== ''International Congress of Electricians'' Held 24-31 August, in connection with [[Exposition universelle de 1889]]. About 530 participants from at least 11 countries. : Adopted several units, including ''practical units'' of power (watt) and work (joule),<ref>{{Cite encyclopedia | title=Report of the United States Commissioners to the Universal Exposition of 1889 at Paris |url=https://archive.org/stream/cu31924107177093#page/n35/mode/2up|contribution=Congress |access-date=12 April 2018|pages=18-20|date=1891|location=Washington, DC|publisher=Government Printing Office}}</ref><ref name=Tunbridge42>{{cite book | author=Tunbridge, P. | title=Lord Kelvin: His Influence on Electrical Measurements and Units | location=Peter Peregrinus | publisher=London | year=1992 |page=42 | isbn=0-86341-237-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bZUK624LZBMC}}</ref> where 1 watt = 10<sup>7</sup> erg/second, and 1 joule = 10<sup>7</sup> erg.<ref name=K144>{{cite journal |journal=American Journal of Physics |doi= 10.1119/1.4826445|last=Jayson|first=J.S.|title=The Daniell Cell, Ohm’s Law and the Emergence of the International System of Units|arxiv=1512.07306v1|volume=82|date=2015|page=63|bibcode=2014AmJPh..82...60J}}</ref> Considered practical magnetic units, but did not make any resolutions or recommendations.<ref name=Kennelly33-144>{{cite journal |last1=Kennelly |first1=A.E.|date=1933 |title=Conference of the Symbols, Units and Nomenclature (S. U. N.) Commission of the International Union of Pure and Applied Physics (I. P. U.), at Paris, in July, 1932, and Its Results |url= |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America |volume=19 |issue=1 |page=144 |doi=10.1073/pnas.19.1.144 |jstor=85786|access-date= |bibcode=1933PNAS...19..144K|pmc=1085894}}</ref>
===1891 in Frankfurt=== Held 7-12 September,<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Transactions of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers |last=Hering |first=Carl |title=Report of the delegation to the Frankfort electrical Congress |volume=8 |year=1891 |page= 544|doi=10.1109/T-AIEE.1891.5570160}}</ref> in connection with the [[International Electrotechnical Exhibition]]<ref name=Tunbridge42/> (Die Internationale Elektrotechnische Ausstellung 1891), organized by [[Elektrotechnische Gesellschaft]].<ref name=lagerstrom/> [[Galileo Ferraris]] was a vice-president at the conference.<ref>{{cite web|arxiv=1412.6981|title=Einstein and Besso: From Zürich to Milano|page=8|last=Bracco|first=Christian|date=2014|bibcode=2014arXiv1412.6981B}}</ref> There were 715 participants (473 from Germany and 243 from other countries, including Austria, United Kingdom, USA, and France).<ref name=L134>{{cite thesis | last=Lagerstrom | first=L.R. |date=1992 | title=Constructing uniformity: The standardization of international electromagnetic measures, 1860-1912|type=doctoral dissertation |chapter= |publisher=University of California, Berkeley}} p. 134</ref> An official report of the conference was published.<ref>International Elektrotechniker-Congress. ''Bericht uber die Verbandlungen der Hauptversammlungen''. Frankfurt am Main: Johannes Alt, 1892.</ref> : Papers and disucssions were organiszed in five main areas: Theory and Measuring Science; Strong Current Technology; Signalling, Telegraphy, and Telephony; Electrochemistry and Electric Current Applications; and Legislation to Mediate Conflicts between Cities around different currents used for electric lights, telephones, and telegraphs.<ref name=L134/><ref>{{cite web|title=Table of Contents of papers presented in the sections|url=http://www.gbv.de/dms/tib-ub-hannover/355198630.pdf|language=de|accessdate=21 April 2018}}</ref>
===1892 in Edinburgh=== Held in connection with the [[British Association for the Advancement of Science]] annual meeting<ref name=Tunbridge42/><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://ethw.org/System_of_Measurement_Units#Evolution_of_Electromagnetic_System_of_Units|title=System of measurement units|website=Engineering and Technology History Wiki|access-date=13 April 2018}}</ref>
===1896 in Geneva=== Held 4-9 August, in connection with the {{ill|Swiss National Exposition|de|Schweizerische_Landesausstellung#1896_in_Genf}}. Insufficient and late communication about the organization of the Congress hampered widespread participation, so that the conference had about 200 participants, mostly from Switzerland, Austria, Germany and Belgium.<ref name=LagerGenf/>
: Topics for discussion were magnetic units, photometric units, the long-distance transmission of power, the protection of high-tension lines against atmospheric discharge, and the problems and challenges of electric railway operation.<ref name=LagerGenf>{{cite thesis | last=Lagerstrom | first=L.R. |date=1992 | title=Constructing uniformity: The standardization of international electromagnetic measures, 1860-1912|type=doctoral dissertation |pages=198-200 |publisher=University of California, Berkeley}}</ref>
==International Electrotechnical Congress== ===1908 in London=== ''International Conference on Electric Units and Standards''. Held in October. Organized by the Commission on Electric Units and Standards of the [[International Electrotechnical Commission]]<ref name=founding/> : Formal adoption of the "international units" (e.g., international ohm, international ampere), which were proposed originally in the 1893 meeting of the International Electrical Congress in Chicago.<ref name=eb11-p742>{{cite encyclopedia | contribution = Units, Physical | title = Encyclopædia Britannica | volume = 27 | year = 1911 | edition = 11th |url=https://archive.org/stream/encyclopaediabri27chisrich#page/742/mode/1up| pages = 742}}</ref>
===1911 in Turin=== Held 10-17 September, organized by {{Interlanguage link multi|Associazione elettrotecnica italiana|it}} and the [[Italian Electrotechnical Committee]] of the [[International Electrotechnical Commission]]<ref name=Turin>{{cite journal |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=1911|title=The International Electrotechnical Congress of Turin|url=https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?arnumber=4768387 |journal=Transactions of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers |volume=30 |issue=3 |pages=2519 - 2533 |doi=10.1109/T-AIEE.1911.4768387 |access-date=10 Apr 2018}}</ref>
===1915 in San Francisco=== Was to be held 13-18 September, and organized by the [[American Institute of Electrical Engineers]],<ref>{{cite journal |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=1914 |title=International Electrical Congress, San Francisco, 1915 |url=https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?tp=&arnumber=6660692 |journal=Proceedings of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers |volume=33 |issue=7 |pages=216-217 |doi=10.1109/PAIEE.1914.6660692 |access-date=10 Apr 2018}}</ref> but was cancelled because of the outbreak of World War I.<ref>{{cite book | author=Tunbridge, P. | title=Lord Kelvin: His Influence on Electrical Measurements and Units | location=Peter Peregrinus | publisher=London | year=1992 |page=53 | isbn=0-86341-237-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bZUK624LZBMC}}</ref>
==Related International Electrotechnical Conferences==
===1905 in Berlin=== ''Internationale Konferenz über Elektrische Masseinheiten'' (International Conference on Electrical Units)
Held 23-25 October at [[Physikalisch-Technischen Reichsanstalt]] at [[Charlottenburg]]. The 1904 Congress recommended holding an international conference to address discrepancies in the electrical units and their interpretation. [[Emil Warburg]], president of the [[Physikalisch-Technische Reichsanstalt]] in Germany, invited representatives from corresponding national laboratories in the United States ([[National Bureau of Standards]]), the United Kingdom ([[National Physical Laboratory (United Kingdom)|National Physical Laboratory]]), and the official standards commissions in Austria and Belgium to an informal conference on electrical standards and units.<ref name=L244>{{cite thesis |last=Lagerstrom |first=L.R. |date=1992 |title=Constructing uniformity: The standardization of international electromagnetic measures, 1860-1912 |type=doctoral dissertation |chapter= |publisher=University of California, Berkeley |url= |access-date=}}pp. 243-244</ref> Additionally Mascart (France), Rayleigh (United Kingdom) and [[Henry Smith Carhart |Carhart]] (USA) were invited because of their expertise and influence.<ref name=L244/> Thirteen of the fifteen invited persons participated in the conference, six from the Reichsanstalt, two from the Belgian Commission on Electrical Units, two from the Austrian Commission on Standardization, [[Richard Glazebrook]] from the National Physical Laboratory, Mascart, and Carhart. The non-attendees were [[Samuel Wesley Stratton]], director of the National Bureau of Standard, who sent three papers outlining the positions and proposals of the Bureau, and Rayleigh.<ref>{{cite thesis |last=Lagerstrom |first=L.R. |date=1992 |title=Constructing uniformity: The standardization of international electromagnetic measures, 1860-1912 |type=doctoral dissertation |chapter= |publisher=University of California, Berkeley |url= |access-date=}}p. 245</ref> A proceedings was published.<ref>{{cite book |title=Verhandlungen der Internationalen konferenz über elektrische masseinheiten abgehalten in der Physikalischtechnischen reichsanstalt zu Charlottenburg vom 23. bis 25. oktober 1905 |date=1906 |author=Internationale Konferenz über Elektrische Masseinheiten |publisher=Reichsdruckerei |url=https://books.google.com?id=TKD2ZwEACAAJ |access-date=17 April 2018}}</ref>
: Concentrated on the redefinition of the ohm, ampere, and volt, as resolved in the 1904 Congress. The aim was to attain true international uniformity in definitions of these concepts.<ref>{{cite thesis |last=Lagerstrom |first=L.R. |date=1992 |title=Constructing uniformity: The standardization of international electromagnetic measures, 1860-1912 |type=doctoral dissertation |chapter= |publisher=University of California, Berkeley |url= |access-date=}}p. 351 </ref> The main question was whether ''ohm'', ''ampere'', and ''volt'' should be independent of each other, or only two should be defined, and which two.<ref name=Tunbridge49>{{cite book | author=Tunbridge, P. | title=Lord Kelvin: His Influence on Electrical Measurements and Units | location=Peter Peregrinus | publisher=London | year=1992 |pages=49-51| isbn=0-86341-237-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bZUK624LZBMC}}</ref> The conference concluded that only two electrical units should be taken as fundamental: the [[Ohm#international ohm|international ohm]] and the [[international ampere]].<ref name=Tunbridge49/> It also adopted the Western Cadmium Cell as the standard cell,<ref name=Tunbridge49/> and added rules about the preparation and use of the mercury tube, whose geometry was specified at the 1893 Congress.<ref>{{cite thesis |last=Lagerstrom |first=L.R. |date=1992 |title=Constructing uniformity: The standardization of international electromagnetic measures, 1860-1912 |type=doctoral dissertation |chapter= |publisher=University of California, Berkeley |url= |access-date=}}p. 247</ref> The conference resolved that another international conference in the course of a year should be held to establish an agreement about the electric standards in use, because different countries had different laws about electrical units.<ref name=Tunbridge49/>
===1908 in Marseille=== Held 14-19 September, in connection with the L'exposition internationale des applications de l'électricité.<ref name=Turin/> A three-volume proceedings was published.<ref>{{cite book |author= |title= Congrès international des applications de l'électricité Marseille (3 vol.)|url= |publisher=Gauthier-Villars |page= |date=1909 |location=Paris|language=fr}}</ref>

{{Infobox person |name = Joseph Aloysius McCahery |image = |caption = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1956|04|14}} |birth_place = [[Montclair, New Jersey]] [http://www.albumacademicum.uva.nl Prof. dr. J.A. McCahery, 1956 -] at the University of Amsterdam ''Album Academicum'' website. |death_date = |death_place = |other_names = |known_for = Investment funds regulation |alma_mater = [[University of Michigan]] (1985)
[[City University of New York|City University of New York at Queens College]] (1988) |occupation = [[Corporate lawyer]] |employer = [[Tilburg University]] |nationality = [[United States]] |parents = }} '''Joseph Aloysius McCahery''' is an academic researcher, corporate lawyer and institutional adviser. McCahery is most notable for his contribution in [[corporate finance]] and [[United States corporate law|law]], [[European law|European]] business law, financial markets and banking regulations, the political economy of [[federalism]] and taxation.Bratton, William W., and Joseph A. McCahery. "The Equilibrium Content of Corporate Federalism." ''Wake Forest Law Review'' 41.3 (2006): 619.Bratton, William W., and Joseph A. McCahery. "Tax coordination and tax competition in the European Union: evaluating the Code of Conduct on Business Taxation." ''Common Market Law Review'' 38.3 (2001): 677-718. As of 2015, McCahery is a professor of International Economic Law and the Financial Market Regulation at [[Tilburg University]].Versterk de Ondernemingskamer. Het Financieel Dagblad Woensdag 20 December, p. 9 (with L. Bouchez). As of the same year, McCahery is a director of the LLM Program at the [[Duisenberg School of Finance]]. During his career McCahery had served as a legal consultant for the [[Centre for European Policy Studies|Center for European Policy Studies]], Monitoring Committee Corporate Governance, [[Ministry of Finance (Netherlands)|The Netherlands Ministry of Finance]] and [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD]],{{Cite web|title = Approachable Professor|url = http://www.law.auckland.ac.nz/en/about/news/news-stories/news-2014/2014/09/approachable-professor-thrives-on-the-challenge-of-complex-resea.html|website = www.law.auckland.ac.nz|accessdate = 2015-05-07}}{{Cite web|title = Küresel Mali Piyasalar ve Düzenlemelerin Geleceği - Global Financial Markets and Future of Regulation|url = http://www.spk.gov.tr/filesys/financial_markets/cv/JosephAMcCahery.html|website = spk.gov.tr|accessdate = 2015-05-07|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150924104556/http://www.spk.gov.tr/filesys/financial_markets/cv/JosephAMcCahery.html|archivedate = 2015-09-24|df = }} == Background == McCahery received his B.A. at the [[University of Michigan]] in 1985. Upon completion of his bachelor's degree, McCahery obtained [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] at the [[City University of New York|City University of New York at Queens College]] in May 1988. From 1991 till 1992, McCahery attended [[University of Oxford|Oxford University]] the Faculty of Law and Centre for Socio-Legal Studies. In 1998 McCahery received his Ph.D. in Law at [[University of Warwick]]. His earliest publication was on the regulatory competition, economic regulation and law.{{Cite web|title = Biography of Professor Joseph McCahery|url = http://www.ecgi.org/members_directory/member.php?member_id=86|website =ecgi.org|accessdate = 2015-05-07}} == Career == McCahery began his legal practice career in 1985 as a law clerk at the Winthrop Stimson Putnam & Roberts. In 1988 he worked as a summer associate for Meagher & Flom in New York. From 1988 till 1989 he worked as a judicial clerk at the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, Cincinnati, Ohio. In 1989, McCahery started his academic career as a visiting lecturer at the Warwick University in England. In 1992 he became the full-time lecturer. In 1997 he started working as an associate professor in Private Law and Center for Law at Tilburg University in Netherlands. From 1998 till 2002, McCahery worked as a visiting faculty at the LLM Program at [[Leiden University]].{{Cite web|title = McCahery, Joseph A. Jr.|url = http://search.usi.ch/people/35b917ef71639846512f6ca53863d1ab/McCahery-Joseph-A-Jr|website = Università della Svizzera italiana|accessdate = 2015-05-07}}{{Cite web|url = http://aei.pitt.edu/9562/2/9562.pdf |title = The Economics of the Proposed European Takeover Directive | date = 2003-01-03|accessdate = 2015-05-07|website =aei.pitt.edu/|publisher = The Centre for European Policy Studies |last = |first = |isbn = 9290794283 }} In 2002 he resumed his career at the Tilburg University as a professor of international business law. From 2005 he worked as professor of corporate governance and innovation at the [[University of Amsterdam]]. He began his career at Duisenberg School of Finance in 2008, where he offers lectures to MSc students in M&A law and transactions, hedge funds and investment management regulation. In 2000, McCahery was awarded a prize for one of the best corporate and securities articles of the year.{{Cite web|url = http://www.cfasociety.org/netherlands/Documents/Speaker%20Profiles%20Hedge%20Funds.pdf|title = CFA Society Netherlands|date = 2012-10-02|accessdate = 2015-05-07|website = cfasociety.org|publisher = CFA|last = |first = }}{{Cite web|title = Researcher Profiles|url = http://www.lexresearch.nl/our_team.htm|website = lexresearch.nl|accessdate = 2015-05-07}} == Research and publications == McCahery had contributed to the literature on cross-border tax cooperation, effects of the corporate federalism, limitations of the corporate governance principles. McCahery is most notable for his research on topics of institutional investment principles, studies of M&A waves and investment funds regulations.Bratton, William W., and Joseph A. McCahery. "Comparative corporate governance and the theory of the firm: The case against global cross reference." ''Colum. J. Transnat'l L.'' 38 (1999): 213. His recent works on corporate governance principles has been dedicated to the analysis of the contractual formations of the venture capital companies and early stage investment general partnership firms.McCahery, Joseph A., Zacharias Sautner, and Laura T. Starks. "Behind the scenes: The corporate governance preferences of institutional investors." ''AFA 2011 Denver Meetings Paper''. 2011. == Books == * W. Bratton & J. [[File:Logemann Family in charity gala.png|thumb|350x350px|Eduardo Logemann; Flavia Alvarez; Elizabeth Logemann; Segio Butori; Manoel Almeida; João Manoel Logemann; Ana Logemann; Luciane Logemann; Marcelo Logemann]] {{Orphan|date=October 2016}}
The '''Logemann Family''' is a Brazilian family of northern German descent. They operate as a family enterprise, and have a full stake in Grupo SLC, a conglomerate of agroindustrial companies, one of them being [[SLC Agrícola]] , an agricultural company and land-holding corporation with properties totalling around {{convert|400000|ha|sqmi}}, which ranks the Logemann Family as the 53rd largest private landowner globally.<ref name=Lovemoney>{{cite web|title=The World's biggest private landowners|url=https://www.lovemoney.com/galleries/70168/revealed-the-worlds-biggest-private-landowners?page=49 |website=lovemoney.com|accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref>
The family, after selling their [[John Deere]] stake in 1999, heavily invested in cotton, which placed them at the very top of global production. <ref name=IstoéDinheiro>{{cite web|title=Os Novos Reis do Algodão|url=https://www.istoedinheiro.com.br/noticias/negocios/20040406/novos-reis-algodao/17418|website=istoedinheiro.com.br|accessdate=15 May 2018}}</ref>
All family members live in [[Porto Alegre]], the capital of Brazil's southern-most state [[Rio Grande do Sul]]. According to ''[[Forbes]]'' in 2014, the family shares a 3 billion-dollar empire divided between 19 blood members.<ref name="Forbes">{{cite web|title=The Complete List Of the 150 Richest of Brazil|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/andersonantunes/2014/09/18/the-complete-list-with-the-150-richest-people-in-brazil/#28dd34ac7968|website=Forbes.com|accessdate=27 October 2016}}</ref>
The family has kept away from media attention, valuing discretion above all else.
== Business Activities==
The Logemann family began its business activities with Frederico Jorge Logemann, who founded Schneider & Logemann Cia LDTA. This company had a humble shop that repaired and manufactured agricultural tools for the village. Upon development, the company began producing their own threshers.<ref name="SLC">{{cite web|title= Historia da SLC|url=http://www.slc.com.br/?page_id=4 |accessdate=15 May 2018}}</ref> Jorge Antonio Dahne Logemann then took control upon his father's death, and began development of automotive harvesting machines, being the first of the Southern Hemisphere to ever produce one. Mr. Jorge Logemann then founded [[SLC Agrícola]] in 1977 (now the family's main business) and in 1979 he merged SLC with [[John Deere]] for a [[Joint venture]] in Brazil.<ref name="SLC">{{cite web|title= Historia da SLC|url=http://www.slc.com.br/?page_id=4 |accessdate=15 May 2018}}</ref> In 1987, Mr. Jorge Antonio Logemann passes away, and his two sons Eduardo and Jorge Luis took leadership of the family's businesses. In 1999, Eduardo and Jorge sell SLC & John Deere back to the John Deere group, and exit the business of tool and machine fabrication.<ref name="SLC">{{cite web|title= Historia da SLC|url=http://www.slc.com.br/?page_id=4 |accessdate=15 May 2018}}</ref> In 2007, the family issues shares of [[SLC Agricola]] in [[B3 (stock exchange)]], which allowed [[SLC Agrícola]] to become one of the 10 most important company of [[Rio Grande do Sul]].<ref name="SLC">{{cite web|title= Historia da SLC|url=http://www.slc.com.br/?page_id=4 |accessdate=15 May 2018}}</ref> In 2017, the family sold one of their businesses, Ferramentas Gerias, to Grupo OVD for an undisclosed amount.<ref name="Amanha">{{cite web|title= Paranaense OVD anuncia compra da Ferramentas Gerais|url=http://www.amanha.com.br/posts/view/4835|website=amanha.com.br|accessdate=15 May 2018}}</ref>
<ref name="SLC">{{cite web|title= Historia da SLC|url=http://www.slc.com.br/?page_id=4 |accessdate=15 May 2018}}</ref>
== Notable Members== '''Frederico Jorge Logemann''', German engineer from [[Bremen]], founds in 1927 the village of Belo Horizonte, today's [[Horizontina]]. In 1945 he and his partner Balduíno Schneider found Schneider & Logemann Cia LTDA, focused in the fabrication and maintenance of agricultural tools. Two years after, the company constructed its first thresher. Mr. Logemann passed away in 1947, after which his only son, Jorge Antonio Dahne Logemann, continued his work.<ref name=SLC>{{cite web|title=Grupo SLC|url=http://www.slc.com.br/?page_id=4|accessdate=15 May 2018}}</ref>
'''Zaira Logemann''', who passed away in 2017, was the oldest member of the family since 1987, belonging to the second generation. She was married to Jorge Antonio Logemann, the member responsible for the creation of SLC and the joint venture with John Deere in 1977. Mrs. Zaira has also been at the forefront of a construction for a new hospital wing in Porto Alegre, which now take on her name. <ref name=Yooying>{{cite web|title=Voluntárias Pela Vida|url=https://www.yooying.com/p/1639147107415163015|website=yooring.com|accessdate=15 May 2018}}</ref>
'''Eduardo Logemann''', eldest son of Zaira, is the current chairman of the family's companies. He is connected to seven different boards, and served as vice president of [[Federação das Indústrias do Estado do Rio Grande do Sul]].<ref name="Federação das Indústrias do Estado do Rio Grande do Sul">{{cite web|title=Eduardo Silva Logemann Executive Profile|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=36508873&privcapId=35016821|website=bloomberg.com|accessdate=27 October 2016}}</ref> [[File:Sr.-Eduardo-Logemann-2.jpg|thumb|260x260px|Eduardo Logemann in SLC Group HQ]]

{{Infobox scientist |name = Mark Abrams |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1906|04|27}} |birth_place = |death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1994|09|25|1906|04|27}} |death_place = |nationality = British |fields = [[Market research]], [[Social policy]], [[Youth culture]], [[Gerontology]] |workplaces = |alma_mater = [[London School of Economics]] |doctoral_advisor = |academic_advisors = |doctoral_students = |notable_students = |known_for = |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |awards = |religion = |spouse = |signature = |footnotes = }}
'''Mark Abrams''' (27 April 1906 – 25 September 1994) was a social scientist and market research expert who pioneered new techniques in statistical surveying and opinion polling.
==Background and education==
Mark Abrams was born Max Alexander Abramowitz in Edmonton, North London in 1906 to Jewish parents who had emigrated from Lithuania and Latvia to the [[East End of London]] in the 1890s.<ref>{{cite web|title=Oxford ODNB: Abrams, Mark Alexander|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/54696}}</ref> He later described his father Abram Abramowitz, a journeyman bootmaker, shopkeeper, and house agent, as a 'philosophical anarchist'.<ref>{{cite web|title=An interview with Mark Abrams (19 September 1984) 1. Family Origins|url=http://surveyresearch.weebly.com/an-interview-with-mark-abrams-audio-files.html}}</ref>
Abrams received a scholarship to attend [[The Latymer School]], then read economics at the [[London School of Economics]]. He went on to complete a PhD in early modern English economic history under the supervision of [[R. H. Tawney]] in 1929.<ref>Mark Abrams, 'The Gold and Silver Thread Monopolies of James I', unpublished PhD dissertation, London School of Economics, 1929.</ref>
==Career==
Between 1931-1933 Abrams was a research fellow at the progressive [[Brookings Institution]] in Washington, DC. In 1933 he joined the research department of the [[London Press Exchange]], one of Britain's leading advertising agencies. Here Abrams began developing his pioneering work in social investigation, market research, and opinion polling by conducting large-scale statistical surveys into consumer behaviour. His national newspaper readership surveys, which included over 20,000 participants between 1934-38, were landmarks in survey research and were credited with establishing the widespread use of the [[NRS social grade|ABC1 system]] of social classification in Britain.<ref>Dawn Mitchell, 'Research for the Truth: Mark Abrams (1906-1994), ''Guardian'', 27 September 1994.</ref> Abrams's contacts with other social scientists working abroad during this period led to his work retrieving refugees from [[Nazi]] Europe (in 1939 helping [[Sigmund Freud]] make his final move to England).<ref>{{cite web|title=Oxford ODNB: Abrams, Mark Alexander|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/54696}}</ref>
During [[World War Two]] Abrams was employed first in the [[BBC]] Overseas Research Department, then at the Psychological Warfare Board, where he carried out government surveys into working-class diets under rationing and the impact of bombing on civilian morale, and also commissioned covert psychological analysis into the mind of [[Adolf Hitler]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Inside Hitler's Mind, University of Cambridge Research (4 May 2012).|url=http://www.cam.ac.uk/research/news/inside-hitlers-mind}}</ref> His studies of food consumption during the war contributed to the establishment of the National Food Survey in 1940.<ref>{{cite web|title=UK Data Service: National Food Survey 1940-2000|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/54696}}</ref>
Abrams returned to the London Press Exchange in 1946 to direct its research department as an independent subsidiary consultancy, Research Services Ltd. By the early 1960s the company employed over ninety members of staff and produced surveys for 300 clients a year, including academic as well as commercial, political, and public sector organisations.<ref>Stefan Schwarzkopf, 'The Statisticalization of the Consumer in British Market Research, c. 1920-1960: Profiling a Good Society', in Glen O'Hara and Tom Crook (eds.), ''Statistics and the Public Sphere: Numbers and the People in Modern Britain'' (London: Routledge, 2012), pp. 144-62.</ref> Research Services Ltd. was commissioned to undertake social surveys prior to the building of [[Peterlee]] new town and the establishment of [[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]] newspaper.<ref>Lawrence Black, 'The Impression of Affluence: Political Culture in the 1950s and 1960s', in Lawrence Black and Hugh Pemberton (eds.) ''An Affluent Society? Britain's Post-War 'Golden Age' Revisited'' (Aldershot: Ashgate, 2004), p. 99; Mark Clapson, 'The Rise and Fall of Monica Felton, British Town Planner and Peace Activist, 1930s to 1950s', ''Planning Perspectives'', 30:2 (2015): 216.</ref> Abrams, along with contemporary pollsters such as [[Henry William Durant|Henry Durant]] of the [[British Institute of Public Opinion]], gained a reputation as an expert authority on market research and mass communication techniques in Britain, and published widely in academic journals as well as newspapers and the popular press.<ref>Joe Moran, 'Mass Observation, Market Research, and the Birth of the Focus Group 1937-1997', ''Journal of British Studies'' 47:4 (2008): 827-51.</ref> Two of his most influential market research reports coined the phrase 'teenage consumer'<ref>Mark Abrams, ''The Teenage Consumer'' (London: London Press Exchange, 1959) and Mark Abrams, ''Teenage Consumer Spending in 1959'' (London: London Press Exchange, 1961).</ref>, drawing attention to the new significance of a rapidly expanding youth market for products and advertising.<ref>Sean Nixon, 'Understanding Ordinary Women: Advertising, Consumer Research and Mass Consumption in Britain, 1948-67', ''Journal of Cultural Economy'', 2:3 (2009): fn. 14, p. 320; [[David Kynaston]], ''Modernity Britain, 1957-62'' (London: Bloomsbury, 2013), p. 341. cf. David Fowler, ''The First Teenagers: The Lifestyle of Young Wage-Earners in Interwar Britain'' (Oxford: Routledge, 1995) pp. 93-94</ref> Abrams was one of the founding members of the [[Market Research Society]] and an advisor of the [[Which?|Consumers' Association]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Market Research Society: History|url=https://www.mrs.org.uk/mrs/history}}</ref> Research Services Ltd. (later known as RSL) was one of the founder companies of [[Ipsos MORI]].
From the mid-1950s Abrams became closely connected with the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] and carried out many of their private opinion polls, first with the modernisers in the party aligned with [[Hugh Gaitskell]] and then [[Harold Wilson]], for whom he worked on the development of Labour's publicity campaign for the [[United Kingdom general election, 1964|1964 general election]].<ref>Dominic Wring, ''The Politics of Marketing the Labour Party'' (Basingstoke: Palgrave Macmillan, 2005), pp. 67-70.</ref>
Abrams left his chairmanship of Research Services Limited in 1970 to become Director of the Survey Research Unit at the [[Economic and Social Research Council|Social Science Research Council]], under [[Michael Young, Baron Young of Dartington|Michael Young]]. Between 1971 and 1975 he worked on the 'Quality of Life in Britain' surveys, which included the innovative use of 'subjective social indicators' to track perceptions of social change.<ref>Scott Anthony, 'Governing for Happiness: Mark Abrams, Subjective Social Indicators and the Post-war Explosion of 'Middle-Opinion', in Don Leggett and Charlotte Sleigh (eds.), ''Scientific Governance in Britain, 1914-79'' (Manchester: Manchester University Press, 2016), pp. 274-94.</ref> Between 1976-1985, Abrams was Research Director at the Age Concern Institute of Gerontology, King's College London, where he undertook studies of living standards among people aged 65 and over. He was also Vice-President of the [[Policy Studies Institute]] between 1978-1994.
==Publications== *''Money and a Changing Civilisation'' (London: John Lane, 1934) *''The Population of Great Britain'' (London: Allen & Unwin, 1945) *''The Condition of the British People, 1911-1946'' (London: Gollancz, 1947) *''Social Surveys and Social Action'' (London: Heinemann, 1951) *''The Teenage Consumer'' (London: London Press Exchange, 1959) *''Must Labour Lose?'' (Harmondsworth: Penguin, 1960), with Richard Rose and Rita Hinden *''The Newspaper Reading Public of Tomorrow'' (London: Odhams, 1964) *''Beyond Three Score and Ten'' (Mitcham: Age Concern, 1980) *''People in Their Sixties'' (Mitcham: Age Concern, 1983) *''Values and Social Change'' (Basingstoke: Macmillan, 1985), with David Gerard and Noel Timms
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{external media | width = 210px | align = right | headerimage= [[File:Horiba model mexa-200 infrared co analyzer PP2007.028.002.jpg|210px]] | video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ymt1NV-vios The Horiba Mexa-200: “a major element in protecting air quality and combating smog”], [[Science History Institute]]}}
{{Nihongo|'''Masao Horiba'''|堀場 雅夫|Horiba Masao| December 1, 1924 – July 14, 2015}} was a Japanese businessman. In 1945, he founded Horiba Radio Laboratory, now [[Horiba|Horiba Ltd.]], a manufacturer of advanced analytical and measurement technology. Masao Horiba received several awards from the Japanese government including a national [[Medals of Honor (Japan)|Blue Ribbon Medal]], and was the first non-American to receive the [[Pittcon Heritage Award]].<ref name=Magazine />
== Early life and education == Masao Horiba was born on December 1, 1924,<ref name=OralHistory /> in [[Shimogyō-ku, Kyoto]], Japan. He was the second son of Shinkichi Horiba, a chemistry professor at Kyoto Imperial University, and his wife Mikiko.<ref name=Kwansei>{{cite web|title=Masao Horiba|url=http://www.kwansei-ac.jp/iba/entre/en/library/vol8.html|publisher=Center for Research in Business, Kwansei Gakuin University|accessdate=March 21, 2014}}</ref> As a child, Horiba suffered from juvenile rheumatoid arthritis.<ref name=OralHistory>{{cite web|author=Center for Oral History| title= Masao Horiba |url=https://oh.sciencehistory.org/oral-histories/horiba-masao|website= [[Science History Institute]] }}</ref><ref name="transcript">{{cite book|first=David C. |last=Brock |title=Masao Horiba, Transcript of Interviews Conducted by David C. Brock at HORIBA, Ltd. Kyoto, Japan on 19 and 20 November 2004 |date=20 November 2004 |url=https://oh.sciencehistory.org/sites/default/files/horiba_m_0305_suppl.pdf|place=Philadelphia, PA|publisher=[[Science History Institute|Chemical Heritage Foundation]] }}</ref> He attended Kyoto Teachers' School's Elementary School and Konan Junior High and Senior High Schools in [[Kobe]], Japan.<ref name=Kwansei />
Originally interested in mathematics and astronomy, Horiba was introduced to nuclear physics by one of his high school teachers<ref name=Speech2011 /> at the Konan Boys' High School.<ref name=OralHistory /> He received a B.S. in physics,<ref name=OralHistory /> and hoped to study nuclear physics with [[Bunsaku Arakatsu]] at [[Kyoto University]]. However, further study in nuclear physics was not possible in post-war Japan. The American authorities had banned such study, and instruments and testing devices had been removed or destroyed.<ref name=Kwansei /><ref name=Speech2011>{{cite journal|last=Horiba|first=Masao|title=Speech In Honouring the Masao Horiba Award Winners|journal=Readout (English edition)|publisher=Horiba Technical Reports|date=February 2011|issue=14|url=http://www.horiba.com/uploads/media/R14E_03_01.pdf|accessdate=March 21, 2014}}</ref>
== Establishing a company == Horiba, who was in his second year at Kyoto University, left the university in 1945 to start his own business, Horiba Radio Laboratory (HRL). In addition to producing electronic parts and repairing electronic instruments, they reconditioned batteries.<ref name=Magazine /> The power distribution system after the war was unreliable, so there was a strong demand for storage batteries for electric lights that could be used in the case of blackouts. Horiba acquired discarded storage batteries and selenium rectifiers which the company Nihon Denchi had produced for wartime use.<ref name=Speech2011/> Sales of Horiba's reconditioned "Teidento" batteries were a profitable source of income for the Horiba company.<ref name=Magazine />
One of the instruments that Horiba produced and repaired was an electric-pulse oscillator, used in brain surgery. When an oscillator stopped working in the middle of an operation, Masao Horiba was called upon to make emergency repairs. He got the instrument working so the surgeons could finish the operation, and then took the instrument home to examine it in more detail. Examination of the components showed that an [[electrolytic capacitor]] had failed. When it proved difficult to buy low-cost reliable replacements, Horiba started producing electrolytic capacitors. By integrating [[quality control]] into the production process, he was able to produce high-quality products. He partnered with an investor but their plans to build a capacitor plant fell through when the Korean war caused Japanese metal prices to rise.<ref name=Magazine />
One of the instruments needed for the capacitor manufacturing processes was the [[pH meter]]. Imported pH meters tended to be unreliable, possibly because of Japan's hot and humid climate.<ref name=OralHistory /> They were also expensive. Rather than buy imported pH meters, Horiba had built his own pH meters for capacitor testing.<ref name=Magazine /> He saw a potential market for reliable, low-cost pH meters in Japan's food and chemical industries, and partnered with Kitahama Works, a major scientific instruments company, to sell them. The pH meters were sold to [[fertilizer]] plants throughout Japan to monitor pH levels in the production of [[ammonium sulfate]] fertilizer for use in [[rice]] production.<ref name=Speech2011 /> In 1953, "Horiba Radio Laboratory" was renamed "Horiba Ltd."<ref name=Magazine />
==Technology development==
Masao Horiba continued to look for new opportunities for his company. After investigating [[gas chromatography]], Horiba decided instead to develop instruments for [[Infrared spectroscopy|infrared analysis]]. The Horiba company already had some experience in creating [[Boule (crystal)|synthetic single crystals]] for use in infrared instruments. With support from the Japanese [[Ministry of International Trade and Industry]], the first Horiba IR infrared-based gas analyzer was sold in 1958, followed by a model for industrial use in 1962.<ref name=Magazine />
Masao Horiba visited the United States in 1958 as part of a study tour for delegates approved by the Japan Productivity Center. He was particularly interested in seeing the [[National Institute of Standards and Technology|National Bureau of Standards]].<ref name=Speech2011 /> During this trip, he also met representatives of [[Hitachi|Hitachi, Ltd.]], beginning a relationship with the Hitachi company.<ref name=Kwansei /><ref name=OralHistory />
The next major product developed at the Horiba company resulted from the work of Masahiro Oura, a young researcher who saw the potential for an [[Motor vehicle emissions|auto-emissions]] measurement instrument. Masao Horiba supported the project once he learned that Oura had orders from several major automobile manufacturers. The company's MEXA-1 air emissions analyzer, which came out in 1964, was the first in a series of analysis devices of increasing sensitivity. The MEXA-1 became important for the company's international expansion. In 1970, Horiba partnered with (and later acquired) Olson Laboratories, expanding into Europe and the UK.<ref name=Magazine /> In 1975, a MEXA analyzer was sold to the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA). The Horiba model MEXA-200 infrared CO analyzer was adopted by the EPA for the regulation auto emissions.<ref name=MexaVideo>{{cite web|title=Horiba Mexa-200|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/horiba-mexa-200-co-analyzer|publisher=Science History Institute|accessdate=26 March 2018 }}</ref> MEXA systems were bought by [[Mercedes-Benz]] in Germany, and [[Renault]] in France.<ref name=Magazine />
==Writing and lecturing== In 1978, at the age of 53, Horiba became chairman of the company, passing the role of president to Masahiro Oura. In 1992, Oura was succeeded by [[Atsushi Horiba]], Horiba's son.<ref name=Magazine />
Horiba actively promoted [[venture capital]] investment, particularly in the Kyoto area, as an adviser to the Advanced Software Technology and Mechatronics Research Institute of Kyoto (ASTEM), one of the largest start-up incubator organizations in Japan. He was a representative of the Japan Association of New Business Incubation Organization (JANBO) which was established in 1999 as a nationwide network for the support of new businesses in Japan. He served as the chairman of the Innovation Initiative Network Japan (Innovation-Net) established in 2009 to revitalize regional economies by promoting collaboration between industries and universities.<ref name=Innovation-Net>{{cite web|title=Winner of the METI Minister’s Award under the Third Commendation Program for Supporting Regional Industries (Innovation-Net Award 2014)|url=http://www.meti.go.jp/english/press/2014/0314_02.html|publisher=Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry|accessdate=March 21, 2014}}</ref> Masao Horiba was also a founder and past president of the Association of Asian Business Incubation (AABI) which encourages support of initiatives throughout Asia, not just in Japan.<ref name=Magazine />
Horiba wrote and lectured on [[business]] and [[management]]. He published several books, including ''Keiei Kokoroe-cho'' (''The Management Handbook'') and ''Iyanara Yamero'' (''Joy and Fun'').<ref name=Magazine /> Horiba promoted the corporate philosophy of ''Omoshiro Okashiku'' or ''Live Merrily and Cheerfully''.<ref name=Kwansei /> He advocated that work should be meaningful and fulfilling, and that employees should be encouraged to be creative, take risks, and question accepted practices. Employers are encouraged to "let the nail stand out", a significant departure from the Japanese [[adage]] that "The nail that stands out gets beaten down."<ref name=Magazine>{{cite journal|last=Ulrych|first=Richard|title=A Japanese instrument pioneer|journal=Chemical Heritage Magazine|year=2004 |volume=22 |issue=1 |pages=12–13, 35–37 |accessdate=March 21, 2014|url=http://pdc-connection.ebscohost.com/c/articles/12722282/japanese-instrument-pioneer}}</ref>
==Awards== The Masao Horiba Awards were established through the Horiba company to recognize young scientists in analytical science, outside the group companies, "who are devoting themselves to research and development of innovative technology in analysis and measurement."<ref name=MasaoAwards>{{cite web|title=Masao Horiba Awards|url=http://www.horiba.com/about-horiba/technical-expertise/masao-horiba-awards/|publisher=Horiba|accessdate=March 21, 2014}}</ref>
In 1982, Horiba received the [[Medals of Honor (Japan)|Blue Ribbon Medal of Honor]] from the Government of Japan, awarded to individuals who have made significant achievements in public service or public welfare.
In recognition of his entrepreneurship and contributions to scientific instrumentation and to society, Masao Horiba was awarded the [[Pittcon Heritage Award]] in 2006, at the [[Pittsburgh Conference on Analytical Chemistry and Applied Spectroscopy]] and the [[Chemical Heritage Foundation]].<ref name="Pittcon">{{cite web|title=Pittcon Heritage Award|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/pittcon-heritage-award|website=[[Science History Institute]]|accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> The award is given to those "whose entrepreneurial careers shaped the instrumentation community, inspired achievement, promoted public understanding of the modern instrumentation sciences, and highlighted the role of analytical chemistry in world economies." <ref name=LCGC>{{cite news|last=Patel-Predd|first=Prachi|title=Masao Horiba gets Pittcon Heritage Award|url=http://www.chromatographyonline.com/lcgc/Misc/Masao-Horiba-gets-Pittcon-Heritage-Award/ArticleStandard/Article/detail/312157|accessdate=March 21, 2014|newspaper=LC GC Chromatography Online|date=March 12, 2006}}</ref> Masao Horiba is the first non-American to receive the Pittcon Award.<ref name=NonAmerican>{{cite news|title=The First Non-American to Receive the Prize and Be Inducted into the Hall of Fame HORIBA's Founder, Masao Horiba Receives Analytical Chemistry Prize|url=http://www.horiba.com/us/en/corporate-news/news/article/the-first-non-american-to-receive-the-prize-and-be-inducted-into-the-hall-of-fame-horibas-founder-masao-horiba-receives-analytical-chemistry-prize-4593/|accessdate=March 22, 2014|newspaper=Horiba Ltd.|date=March 14, 2006}}</ref>
On July 14, 2015, Horiba died in his sleep at the age of 90.<ref name=Official>{{cite web|title=Notice for a Death: Dr. Masao Horiba, Founder and Supreme Counsel of HORIBA, Ltd.|url=http://www.horiba.com/us/en/corporate-news/news/article/notice-for-a-death-dr-masao-horiba-founder-and-supreme-counsel-of-horiba-ltd-39827/|website=HORIBA Explore the Future|publisher=HORIBA, Ltd.|accessdate=July 16, 2015}}</ref><ref name=Nikkei>{{cite news|last1=Takeda |first1=Shinobu |title=Revered postwar entrepreneur just wanted to have fun |url=http://asia.nikkei.com/Life-Arts/Milestone/Revered-postwar-entrepreneur-just-wanted-to-have-fun |accessdate=July 23, 2015 |work=Nikkei Asian Review |date=July 17, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150723224536/http://asia.nikkei.com/Life-Arts/Milestone/Revered-postwar-entrepreneur-just-wanted-to-have-fun |archivedate=July 23, 2015 |df= }}</ref>

'''Matías Campiani''' is an American-educated [[Argentine]] businessman.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/05/15/morning-agenda-hoax-bid-for-avon-points-to-s-e-c-security-hole/ |title=Morning Agenda |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=May 15, 2015}}</ref> He is a former partner of Leadgate, a private equity firm.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=53897939&privcapId=23063068 |title= Matías Campiani Business Biography |publisher=''Bloomberg Business''}}</ref> He is also the former CEO of [[PLUNA]], the national airline of Uruguay.
Campiani was imprisoned in Uruguay without charges from December 2013 to May 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/15/business/dealbook/risky-web-of-privatization-in-uruguay-where-charges-are-optional.html?_r=0 |title=Risky Web of Privatization in Uruguay Where Charges Are Optional |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=May 15, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/22/business/dealbook/private-equity-executive-to-be-released-from-uruguay-prison.html |title=Private Equity Executive To Be Released from Uruguay Prison |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=May 21, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ft.com/content/0ab36768-0013-11e5-abd5-00144feabdc0 |title=Former Airline Chief Campiani Released From Uruguay Prison |publisher=''Financial Times'' |date=May 22, 2015}}</ref>
Gustavo Herrero, executive director of the [[Harvard Business School]] Latin American Research Center, told ''[[The New York Times]]'' that local politics were to blame for the imprisonment of Campiani and his private equity partners, stating they were “ideal scapegoats.” A ''Mercero Press'' report covering the Pluna imprisonment stated that there was a “political” side to Leadgate. According to this article, when Pluna Leadgate was launched in 2007, Agriculture Minister and future president [[José Mujica]] allegedly said: “I don’t like the looks of these cocky Argentines from Buenos Aires.”<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.mercopress.com/2013/12/21/uruguay-economy-minister-resigns-over-scandal-involving-flag-air-carrier-pluna |title=Uruguay Economy Minister Resigns Over Scandal Involving Flag Air Carrier PLUNA |publisher=''Merco Press'' |date=December 21, 2013}}</ref>
In May 2015, the [[Supreme Court of Uruguay]] took up Campiani's appeal for release from jail. He was released on May 22, 2015.<ref>http://www.elpais.com.uy/informacion/campiani-libre-abrio-polemica-sistema.html</ref> No formal charges have been filed against Camipani, as of May 2016.
Campiani holds a master's degree in Industrial Management from [[Carnegie Mellon University]] and a BA degree in Finance and Economics from [[Universidad Católica Argentina]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=53897939&privcapId=23063068 |title= Matías Campiani Business Biography |publisher=''Bloomberg Business''}}</ref>

{{Infobox holiday |type=secular |holiday_name=National Day of Mourning |duration= 1 day |scheduling = 28th day of April |frequency=annual |observedby=Canada |image = |caption= |date=28th day of April |longtype= |week_ordinal= |weekday= |month=April |celebrations=flag at half-mast, [[Moment of silence]], lighting candles, donning ribbons and black armbands |relatedto=[[Labor Day]]; [[Workers' Memorial Day]] }} The '''National Day of Mourning''', or '''Workers’ Mourning Day''' is observed in [[Canada]] on 28 April. It commemorates workers who have been killed, injured or suffered illness due to workplace related hazards and occupational exposures.
Workers' Memorial Day was started when two labour activists, Colin Lambert and Dr. Ray Sentes, were driving in early April 1983 to a union meeting, and were stopped by a funeral procession for a firefighter that had been killed in the line of duty<ref>{{Citation|last=BC Labour Heritage Centre|title=Day of Mourning The Untold Story (2017)|date=2017-04-20|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hP0JvrXjmgo&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2018-05-09}}</ref>. They worried that other workers who died because of work did not receive similar honours, and recalled how members of the United Steelworkers in Elliott Lake held each year a "Workers' Remembrance Day" for uranium miners who had succumbed to exposures. Lambert and Sentes sought endorsements from union officials for the idea to hold a national day of mourning, and the Canadian Union of Public Employees (CUPE) passed a resolution to that effect at its annual convention in 1983, and the Canadian Labour Congress followed suit at its annual convention the following year. The AFL-CIO declared a day of mourning in 1989 and a "workers' Memorial Day" is observed in over 100 countries.
In December 1990, this day became a national observance in Canada with the passing of the Workers Mourning Day Act, so that on April 28, 1991, it was officially the National Day of Mourning for persons killed or injured in the workplace; making April 28, an official Workers’ Mourning Day.<ref name="Manchester">[[Greater Manchester Hazards Centre]] Fact Sheet 28 April 2006 (GMHC is part of the [[Hazards Campaign]] recognised and affiliated to the UK [[Trades Union Congress]]) Author Hilda Palmer, (no ISBN); available at {{cite web |url=http://www.gmhazards.org.uk/WMDLft06.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-03-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060518055811/http://www.gmhazards.org.uk/WMDLft06.pdf |archivedate=2006-05-18 |df= }} Also '''Safety Express' March/ April 2006 Page 5'' 'April 28th is...Workers' Memorial Day' (no ISBN); published by The [[Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents]] ([[ROSPA]]) UK [[registered charity]] No. 207823</ref><ref name="ohs">TUC Certificate in Occupational Health & Safety course notes 2004/5 Section C page 69 (no ISBN); more info available at {{cite web |url=http://www.tuc.org.uk/h_and_s/index.cfm?mins=293 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-03-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100217003146/http://www.tuc.org.uk/h_and_s/index.cfm?mins=293 |archivedate=2010-02-17 |df= }}</ref>
Injuries and deaths in the workplace continue to be a matter of important concern across Canada. Many Canadians members work hard each day in an effort to minimize accidents and incidents. Risk is an inherent element of many jobs, and this is why safety should be one of the core values in any workplace. Since its inception, the observance has spread to over 80 countries around the world, but is known is most other countries as the [[Workers' Memorial Day]]. The date 28 April was picked because on that day in 1914, the [http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/workers-compensation/ Workers Compensation Act] received its third reading. In 2001 the [[International Labour Organization]] first observed World Day for Safety and Health at Work on this day. Commemorating those who have been hurt or killed in the workplace shows respect for the fallen, while serving as a reminder of the importance of occupational health and safety.
The Canadian flag is flown at half-mast from sunrise to sunset on all federal government buildings, including on Parliament Hill. Workers and employees observe this day in various ways including lighting candles, donning ribbons and black armbands, and observing a moment of silence at 1100 hrs. The purpose of Day of Mourning is twofold- to remember and honour those lives lost or injured and to renew the commitment to improving health and safety in the workplace - to prevent further deaths, injuries and diseases from work.
==Young Workers== Young workers aged from 15-24 are more likely than any other group to be injured on the job, in fact 1/3 of all injuries occur in this age group, and males are twice as likely to be injured as female workers.<ref name="YoungStats">[[WorkSafeBC]] Young Workers Rights and Facts, http://www.labourheritagecentre.ca/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/6-FactSheet-Bugged-Revision-3-.pdf.</ref> The highest rate of injury happens in construction and hospitality industries. These rates have led to specific laws in many provinces that provide for additional and special training for young and new workers.<ref name="Young">[[WorkSafeBC]] Young Workers Resource and Fact Page, http://www2.worksafebc.com/Topics/YoungWorker/Home.asp.</ref> Due to these statistics, there has been renewed push to use this holiday to educate young workers of their rights in schools.<ref name="Schools">Day of Mourning, BC Schools Project, http://www.labourheritagecentre.ca/domschoolsproject/</ref>
==Canadian monuments== Major monuments in Canada have been erected and dedicated to workers whose lives have been who have been killed and injured on the job.<ref>{{ccohs|date=2015 04 27|url=http://www.ccohs.ca/events/mourning/ |title=Monuments Canada }}.</ref>
* The Canadian Young Workers Memorial Quilt -The LifeQuilt with individual, personalized quilted blocks commemorated 100 young workers is a memorial dedicated to the thousands of young women and men between the ages of 14 and 24 killed on the job.<ref>{{date=2015 04 27|url=http://lifequilt.ca/ |title=Young Workers Memorial Life Quilt }}.</ref> * [[Canadian Labour Congress]] Monument, [[Vincent Massey Park]], [[Ottawa|Ottawa, Ontario]], Canada - This monument was dedicated on April 28, 1987, one year after the Canadian Labour Congress had officially established April 28 as the Day of Mourning to workers killed and injured on the job.<ref>{{date=2015 04 27|url=http://www.ccohs.ca/events/mourning/labourcongress.html|title="Dead But Not Forgotten–Monuments to Workers" a book by Ed Thomas }}.</ref> * Falconbridge Mural, [[Sudbury, Ontario]], Canada * Miner's Memorial [[Kirkland Lake, Ontario]] Canada * [[Rideau Canal]] Fabric Mural Memorial, [[Kingston, Ontario]], Canada * Fire Fighter's Monument, [[Saskatoon, Saskatchewan]], Canada * "Breaking Ground" Hoggs Hollow Memorial, [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada * 'Their Light Shall Always Shine' Memorial Park, New Glasgow, Nova Scotia is a park and memorial dedicated to the 26 miners who lost their lives in a horrific mining explosion on May 9, 1992. http://ns1763.ca/pictouco/westraymem.html * "Broken Families Obelisk" Grant Notley Park, [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]], Canada * Welland Canal Fallen Workers Memorial, [[St. Catharines]], [[Ontario]], Canada
The [http://www.labourheritagecentre.ca/ BC Labour Heritage Centre] maintains an [http://www.labourheritagecentre.ca/workermemorialmap/ interactive map] recording all monuments and plaques dedicated to working class people in British Columbia, over fifty sites of which are Day of Mourning specific.
==International monuments== Monuments around the world have been erected and dedicated to workers whose lives have been who have been killed and injured on the job.<ref>{{ccohs|date=2015 04 27|url=http://www.ccohs.ca/events/mourning/ |title=Monuments International }}.</ref> * [[Hoover Dam]] Monument, [[Boulder City, Nevada]], USA * Airplane and Fishermen Monument, [[Hedinsfjordur, Iceland]] * Workers Memorial Day Stained Glass Window, [[Birmingham, England]] * Deceased Workers Memorial Forest [Adelaide South Australia} *National Deceased Workers Memorial (Workers Glade) [Canberra Australia]
